Holds an array of url_pattern => controller k/v pairs, the same as Director::rules. However this is built dynamically from introspecting on all the classes that derive from LeftAndMain.
Don't access this directly - always access via the rules() accessor below, which will build this array the first time it's accessed

comment.value: Make director rule
ensure that the first call to add_rule_for_controller for a rule takes precedence
If this is the final portion of the request (i.e. the URL is just /admin), direct to the default panel

var.description: $urlParams An array of arguments extracted from the URL
$requestParams Contains all GET and POST parameters
$action The URL part matched on the current controller as

docblock.var: determined by the "$Action" part of the definition. Should correlate to a public method on this controller. Used in and to determine action-specific templates.

description.compact: The {@link Session} object for this controller
Stack of current controllers.

docblock.description: Controller::$controller_stack[0] is the current controller.

var.description: $response The response object that the controller returns.

description.compact: Initialisation function that is run before any action on the controller is called.

comment.value: Directly access the session variable just in case the Group or Member tables don't yet exist
This is used to test that subordinate controllers are actually calling parent::init() - a common bug

description.compact: Returns a link to this controller. Overload with your own Link rules if they exist.
Executes this controller, and return an {@link SS_HTTPResponse} object with the result.

docblock.description: This method first does a few set-up activities: - Push this controller ont to the controller stack - see for information about this. - Call - Defer to to determine which action should be executed Note: $requestParams['executeForm'] support was removed, make the following change in your URLs: "/?executeForm=FooBar" -> "/FooBar" Also make sure "FooBar" is in the $allowed_actions of your controller class. Note: You should rarely need to overload run() - this kind of change is only really appropriate for things like nested controllers - and are two examples here. If you want to make more orthodox functionality, it's better to overload or . Important: If you are going to overload handleRequest, make sure that you start the method with $this->pushCurrent() and end the method with $this->popCurrent(). Failure to do this will create weird session errors.

return.description: The response that this controller produces,

docblock.return: including HTTP headers such as redirection info

comment.value: If we had a redirection or something, halt processing.

comment.value: If the action returns an array, customise with it before rendering the template.

var.description: $request The request object that the controller was called with.

docblock.var: Set in . Useful to generate the {}

description.compact: The DataModel for this request
This variable records whether RequestHandler::__construct() was called or not. Useful for checking if subclasses have called parent::__construct()

comment.value: Check necessary to avoid class conflicts before manifest is rebuilt
This will prevent bugs if setDataModel() isn't called.

description.compact: Set the DataModel for this request.
Handles URL requests.

docblock.description: - ViewableData::handleRequest() iterates through each rule in . - If the rule matches, the named method will be called. - If there is still more URL to be processed, then handleRequest() is called on the object that that method returns. Once all of the URL has been processed, the final result is returned. However, if the final result is an array, this array is interpreted as being additional template data to customise the 2nd to last result with, rather than an object in its own right. This is most frequently used when a Controller's action will return an array of data with which to customise the controller.

param.description: {@link SS_HTTPRequest} object that is reponsible for distributing URL parsing

comment.value: $handlerClass is used to step up the class hierarchy to implement url_handlers inheritance
If nothing matches, return this object
Start to find what action to call. Start by using what findAction returned
We used to put "handleAction" as the action on controllers, but (a) this could only be called when
you had $Action in your rule, and (b) RequestHandler didn't have one. $Action is better
Deprecation::notice('3.2.0', 'Calling handleAction directly is deprecated - use $Action instead');
Actions can reference URL parameters, eg, '$Action/$ID/$OtherID' => '$Action',
If we return a RequestHandler, call handleRequest() on that, even if there is no more URL to
parse. It might have its own handler. However, we only do this if we haven't just parsed an
empty rule ourselves, to prevent infinite loops. Also prevent further handling of controller
actions which return themselves to avoid infinite loops.
Array results can be used to handle
We stop after RequestHandler; in other words, at ViewableData

description.compact: Given a request, and an action name, call that action name on this RequestHandler

docblock.description: Must not raise SS_HTTPResponse_Exceptions - instead it should return

description.compact: Get a array of allowed actions defined on this controller, any parent classes or extensions.

comment.value: convert all keys and values to lowercase to
allow for easier comparison, unless it is a permission code

description.compact: Checks if this request handler has a specific action, even if the current user cannot access it.

docblock.description: Includes class ancestry and extensions in the checks.

comment.value: Don't allow access to any non-public methods (inspect instance plus all extensions)
Check if the action is defined in the allowed actions of any ancestry class
as either a key or value. Note that if the action is numeric, then keys are not
searched for actions to prevent actual array keys being recognised as actions.

description.compact: Return the class that defines the given action, so that we know where to check allowed_actions.

comment.value: Get actions for this specific class (without inheritance)
check if specific action is set
TRUE should always allow access
If we don't have a match in allowed_actions,
whitelist the 'index' action as well as undefined actions based on configuration.

description.compact: Throws a HTTP error response encased in a {@link SS_HTTPResponse_Exception}, which is later caught in {@link RequestHandler::handleAction()} and returned to the user.

comment.value: Call a handler method such as onBeforeHTTPError404
Call a handler method such as onBeforeHTTPError, passing 404 as the first arg
Throw a new exception

description.compact: Returns the SS_HTTPRequest object that this controller is using.

docblock.description: Returns a placeholder object unless or have been called, which adds a reference to an actual object.

description.compact: Typically the request is set through {@link handleAction()} or {@link handleRequest()}, but in some based we want to set it manually.
A failover object to attempt to get data from if it is not present on this object.
Converts a field spec into an object creator. For example: "Int" becomes "new Int($fieldName);" and "Varchar(50)" becomes "new Varchar($fieldName, 50);".

Convert a field schema (e.g. "Varchar(50)") into a casting object creator array that contains both a className and castingHelper constructor code. See {@link castingObjectCreator} for more information about the constructor.
Check if a field exists on this object or its failover.

Get the value of a property/field on this object. This will check if a method called get{$property} exists, then check if a field is available using {@link ViewableData::getField()}, then fall back on a failover object.
Set a property/field on this object. This will check for the existence of a method called set{$property}, then use the {@link ViewableData::setField()} method.
Check if a field exists on this object. This should be overloaded in child classes.
Get the value of a field on this object. This should be overloaded in child classes.
Set a field on this object. This should be overloaded in child classes.
Add methods from the {@link ViewableData::$failover} object, as well as wrapping any methods prefixed with an underscore into a {@link ViewableData::cachedCall()}.
Merge some arbitrary data in with this object. This method returns a {@link ViewableData_Customised} instance with references to both this and the new custom data.

docblock.description: Note that any fields you specify will take precedence over the fields on this object.

description.compact: Get the class a field on this object would be casted to, as well as the casting helper for casting a field to an object (see {@link ViewableData::castingHelper()} for information on casting helpers).

docblock.description: The returned array contains two keys: - className: the class the field would be casted to (e.g. "Varchar") - castingHelper: the casting helper for casting the field (e.g. "return new Varchar($fieldName)")

description.compact: Return the "casting helper" (a piece of PHP code that when evaluated creates a casted value object) for a field on this object.
Get the class name a field on this object will be casted to
Return the string-format type for the given field.
Save the casting cache for this object (including data from any failovers) into a variable

Render this object into the template, and get the result as a string. You can pass one of the following as the $template parameter: - a template name (e.g. Page) - an array of possible template names - the first valid one will be used - an SSViewer instance

param.description: fields to customise() the object with before rendering

description.compact: Get the value of a field on this object, automatically inserting the value into any available casting objects that have been specified.

param.description: if TRUE, the value will ALWAYS be casted to an object before being returned,

docblock.param: even if there is no explicit casting information

comment.value: HACK: Don't call the deprecated FormField::Name() method

description.compact: A simple wrapper around {@link ViewableData::obj()} that automatically caches the result so it can be used again without re-running the method.
Checks if a given method/field has a valid value. If the result is an object, this will return the result of the exists method, otherwise will check if the result is not just an empty paragraph tag.
Get the string value of a field on this object that has been suitable escaped to be inserted directly into a template.
Return the value of the field without any escaping being applied.
Return the value of a field in an SQL-safe format.
Return the value of a field in a JavaScript-save format.
Return the value of a field escaped suitable to be inserted into an XML node attribute.
Get an array of XML-escaped values by field name
Return a single-item iterator so you can iterate over the fields of a single record.

docblock.description: This is useful so you can use a single record inside a <% control %> block in a template - and then use to access individual fields on this object.

description.compact: When rendering some objects it is necessary to iterate over the object being rendered, to do this, you need access to itself.
Return the directory if the current active theme (relative to the site root).

docblock.description: This method is useful for things such as accessing theme images from your template without hardcoding the theme page - e.g. . This method should only be used when a theme is currently active. However, it will fall over to the current project directory.

description.compact: Get part of the current classes ancestry to be used as a CSS class.

docblock.description: This method returns an escaped string of CSS classes representing the current classes ancestry until it hits a stop point - e.g. "Page DataObject ViewableData".

param.description: the class to stop at (default: ViewableData)

comment.value: optionally add template identifier

List of callbacks to call after extensions having extend called on them, each grouped by methodName.

description.compact: An implementation of the factory method, allows you to create an instance of a class

param.description: ... arguments to pass to the constructor

comment.value: Class to create should be the calling class if not Object,
otherwise the first parameter

description.compact: Create an object from a string representation. It treats it as a PHP constructor without the 'new' keyword. It also manages to construct the object without the use of eval().

docblock.description:
Construction itself is done with Object::create(), so that Object::useCustomClass() calls are respected.
`Object::create_from_string("Versioned('Stage','Live')")` will return the result of `Versioned::create('Stage', 'Live);`
It is designed for simple, clonable objects. The first time this method is called for a given string it is cached, and clones of that object are returned.
If you pass the $firstArg argument, this will be prepended to the constructor arguments. It's impossible to pass null as the firstArg argument.
`Object::create_from_string("Varchar(50)", "MyField")` will return the result of `Vachar::create('MyField', '50');`
Arguments are always strings, although this is a quirk of the current implementation rather than something that can be relied upon.

comment.value: an $extension value can contain parameters as a string,
e.g. "Versioned('Stage','Live')"

description.compact: Parses a class-spec, such as "Versioned('Stage','Live')", as passed to create_from_string().

docblock.description: Returns a 2-elemnent array, with classname and arguments

comment.value: Keep track of the current bucket that we're putting data into
Get the class naem

description.compact: Similar to {@link Object::create()}, except that classes are only overloaded if you set the $strong parameter to TRUE when using {@link Object::useCustomClass()}

param.description: ... arguments to pass to the constructor

description.compact: This class allows you to overload classes with other classes when they are constructed using the factory method {@link Object::create()}

param.description: the class to replace it with
allows you to enforce a certain class replacement under all circumstances. This is used in

description.compact: If a class has been overloaded, get the class name it has been overloaded with - otherwise return the class name

return.description: the class that would be created if you called {@link Object::create()} with the class

description.compact: Get the value of a static property of a class, even in that property is declared protected (but not private), without any inheritance, merging or parent lookup if it doesn't exist on the given class.

param.description: The class to get the static from
The property to get from the class
- The value to return if property doesn't exist on class

return.description: - The value of the static property $name on class $class, or $default if that property is not

description.compact: Get a static variable, taking into account SS's inbuild static caches and pseudo-statics

docblock.description: This method first checks for any extra values added by , and attemps to traverse up the extra static var chain until it reaches the top, or it reaches a replacement static. If any extra values are discovered, they are then merged with the default PHP static values, or in some cases completely replace the default PHP static when you set $replace = true, and do not define extra data on any child classes

param.description: if set to TRUE, force a regeneration of the static cache

description.compact: Set a static variable
Get an uninherited static variable - a variable that is explicity set in this class, and not in the parent class.
Traverse down a class ancestry and attempt to merge all the uninherited static values for a particular static into a single variable

param.description: an optional parent class name to begin merging statics down from, rather than traversing

description.compact: Merge in a set of additional static variables

Add a static variable without replacing it completely if possible, but merging in with both existing PHP statics and existing psuedo-statics. Uses PHP's array_merge_recursive() with if the $replace argument is FALSE.

docblock.description: Documentation from http://php.net/array_merge_recursive: If the input arrays have the same string keys, then the values for these keys are merged together into an array, and this is done recursively, so that if one of the values is an array itself, the function will merge it with a corresponding entry in another array too. If, however, the arrays have the same numeric key, the later value will not overwrite the original value, but will be appended.

description.compact: Return TRUE if a class has a specified extension.

docblock.description: This supports backwards-compatible format (static Object::has_extension($requiredExtension)) and new format ($object->has_extension($class, $requiredExtension))

param.description: if 1 argument supplied, the class name of the extension to

docblock.param: check for; if 2 supplied, the class name to test

param.description: if the extension has to match the required extension and not be a subclass

comment.value: BC support

description.compact: Add an extension to a specific class.

docblock.description: The preferred method for adding extensions is through YAML config, since it avoids autoloading the class, and is easier to override in more specific configurations. As an alternative, extensions can be added to a specific class directly in the array. See for examples. Keep in mind that the extension will only be applied to new instances, not existing ones (including all instances created through ).

param.description: Class that should be extended - has to be a subclass of {@link Object}
Subclass of {@link Extension} with optional parameters

comment.value: unset some caches
load statics now for DataObject classes

description.compact: Remove an extension from a class.

docblock.description: Keep in mind that this won't revert any datamodel additions of the extension at runtime, unless its used before the schema building kicks in (in your _config.php). Doesn't remove the extension from any instances which are already created, but will have an effect on new extensions. Clears any previously created singletons through to avoid side-effects from stale extension information.

todo.value: Add support for removing extensions with parameters

param.description: Classname of an {@link Extension} subclass, without parameters

comment.value: remove any instances of the extension with parameters
extensions with parameters will be stored in config as
unset singletons to avoid side-effects
unset some caches

docblock.param: FALSE would return array("Versioned"), TRUE returns array("Versioned('Stage','Live')").

docblock.return: or eval'ed classname strings with constructor arguments.

docblock.description: All these methods can then be called directly on the instance (transparently mapped through ), or called explicitly through .

description.compact: Add all the methods from an object property (which is an {@link Extension}) to this object.

param.description: an index to use if the property is an array

description.compact: Add a wrapper method - a method which points to another method with a different name. For example, Thumbnail(x) can be wrapped to generateThumbnail(x)

description.compact: Add an extra method using raw PHP code passed as a string

param.description: the PHP code - arguments will be in an array called $args, while you can access this object

docblock.param: by using $obj. Note that you cannot call protected methods, as the method is actually an external function

description.compact: Return true if this object "exists" i.e. has a sensible value

docblock.description: This method should be overriden in subclasses to provide more context about the classes state. For example, a {@link DataObject} class could return false when it is deleted from the database

description.compact: Check if this class is an instance of a specific class, or has that class as one of its parents
Calls a method if available on both this object and all applied {@link Extensions}, and then attempts to merge all results into an array
Run the given function on all of this object's extensions. Note that this method originally returned void, so if you wanted to return results, you're hosed

docblock.description: Currently returns an array, with an index resulting every time the function is called. Only adds returns if they're not NULL, to avoid bogus results from methods just defined on the parent extension. This is important for permission-checks through extend, as they use min() to determine if any of the returns is FALSE. As min() doesn't do type checking, an included NULL return would fail the permission checks. The extension methods are defined during in .

param.description: the name of the method to call on each extension
... up to 7 arguments to be passed to the method

description.compact: Get an extension instance attached to this object by name.

Returns TRUE if this object instance has a specific extension applied in {@link $extension_instances}. Extension instances are initialized at constructor time, meaning if you use {@link add_extension()} afterwards, the added extension will just be added to new instances of the extended class. Use the static method {@link has_extension()} to check if a class (not an instance) has a specific extension.

docblock.description: Caution: Don't use singleton(<class>)->hasExtension() as it will give you inconsistent results based on when the singleton was first accessed.

param.description: Classname of an {@link Extension} subclass without parameters

description.compact: Get all extension instances for this specific object instance.

docblock.description: See to get all applied extension classes for this class (not the instance).

return.description: Map of {@link DataExtension} instances, keyed by classname.

description.compact: Cache the results of an instance method in this object to a file, or if it is already cache return the cached results
Clears the cache for the given cacheToFile call
Loads a cache from the filesystem if a valid on is present and within the specified lifetime

param.description: the lifetime (in seconds) of the cache before it is invalid

description.compact: Save a piece of cached data to the file system
Strip a file name of special characters so it is suitable for use as a cache file name

return.description: the name with all special cahracters replaced with underscores

description.compact: Retrieve an external iterator

Called by SSViewer to get a list of global variables to expose to the template, the static method to call on this class to get the value for those variables, and the class to use for casting the returned value for use in a template

docblock.description:
If the method to call is not included for a particular template variable, a method named the same as the template variable will be called
If the casting class is not specified for a particular template variable, ViewableData::$default_cast is used
The first letter of the template variable is case-insensitive. However the method name is always case sensitive.

return.description: Returns an array of items. Each key => value pair is one of three forms:

docblock.return: - template name (no key) - template name => method name - template name => array(), where the array can contain these key => value pairs - "method" => method name - "casting" => casting class to use (i.e., Varchar, HTMLText, etc)
